FACEBOOK UNVEILS NEW ELECTION, SECURITY MEASURES — The social network is expanding its reward system for people who flag vulnerabilities on the platform and bolstering tools for campaigns to protect themselves from “bad actors.” In a post Monday, Facebook security engineer manager Dan Gurfinkel announced the company would extend its “bug bounty program” to include those who identify problems with third-party apps involving “improper exposure of Facebook user access tokens.” The company received a firestorm of criticism earlier this year when reports emerged that Cambridge Analytica improperly accessed information on millions of Facebook users collected via a third-party quiz app.

— 50 days out: Less than two months out from the midterm elections, Facebook head of cybersecurity policy Nathaniel Gleicher announced in a separate post that “as part of our broader efforts to better secure Facebook, we are launching a pilot program to expand our existing protections for users associated with US political campaigns ahead of the 2018 midterm elections.” The company said the goal of the program is to “stay ahead of bad actors who are determined to use Facebook to disrupt elections.”
